awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EarthCube Data Capabilities: Rapid response to existing community demand through next generation web infrastructure to integrate Argo and GO-SHIP
awd_abstract_narration:
Hydrographic measurements of physical and biogeochemical properties in the ocean support broad research, including carbon content and uptake; ocean heat content, fluxes, and transport; surface and deep current calculations and modeling. At present, two separate data facilities are serving global hydrographic data for their respective programs. Argovis provides access and tools for data from the global array of Argo floats, which profile the oceans to record temperature, salinity, pressure, and an emerging set of biogeochemical measurements. The CLIVAR and Carbon Hydrographic Data Office (CCHDO) serves vessel-based data from the global Global Ocean Ship-based Hydrographic Investigations Program (GO-SHIP), providing reference-quality temperature and salinity data from repeated visits to the same locations, plus a large set of tracer, nutrient, and chemical data from analyzed water samples. The proposed work will create interoperability across these two systems, allowing scientists to search, access, and work with data from both facilities.

This project builds on past and current investments in Argovis and GO-SHIP technologies, informed by the SeaView EarthCube Integrative Activity’s experience integrating across ocean data facilities. As part of the proposed infrastructure, the databases will deliver dynamic data selection via new API capabilities and allow visualizations, co-location, and comparison on web applications otherwise not possible with simple file archives. The project will be aligned with contemporary web standards and practices. Interoperability will allow Argovis users to continue using the interface they are familiar with, with the added ability to search and integrate GO-SHIP data from a user-defined proximity to data in Argovis. GO-SHIP users will similarly be able to transition seamlessly to the new tools from the GOSHIP website and access Argovis data near GO-SHIP lines or profiles of interest. Project outcomes will be inherently sustainable: after development, the long-term maintenance of some of the tools will be covered by the ongoing GO-SHIP core support.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Argovis is a data service built to make ocean data easy to search, filter and download in any programming environment. It accomplishes this by representing many heterogeneous ocean datasets in as homogenous a format as possible, enabling easy colocation and cross-referencing of these disparate datasets, such as Argo and CCHDO (ship-based) oceanic profiles, and many more. Furthermore, Argovis' search and download capabilities are engineered to be fast and entirely automatable, allowing for the consumption of all supported datasets in interactive web applications for education and exploratory purposes, as well as in living analytical documents like Jupyter notebooks which can rapidly integrate new data as it becomes available. Today, Argovis serves thousands of requests for ocean data weekly, both through its interactive web frontend, and increasingly via direct access to its public API. It is used in undergraduate educational activities at several universities, and is used as a backend data service by ocean science projects like GANDALF (the Gulf AUV Network, Data Archive and Layer Fusing).

This grant emphasized the collaborative opportunities behind two major sources of ocean profile data: the Argo program, which operates thousands of autonomous floats probing Earth's oceans; and the GO-SHIP program, or more broadly the ship-based ocean profiles collected and curated by CCHDO, as well as derived products. Both these programs provide decades of measurements (profiles) of the ocean in depth; this project sought to make it a simple matter to colocate and cross-reference these datasets for the purposes of systematic cross-checks and quality control, and to form a more complete picture of ocean variables informed by both these major projects. Argovis accomplished this rapid colocation by standardizing the representation of both these datasets, and providing consistent search parameters across them so that both could be queried for the temporospatial region of interest with identical requests. We furthermore included Easy Ocean, GLODAP, and the Roemmich-Gilson climatology as products derived from observed vertical profiles, covering them with the same query functionality and colocation abilities as the original datasets in order to promote the cross-comparison of these interpolated products similarly to the upstream in-situ measurements. Argovis search capabilities are demoed in publicly available notebooks and were used to build web pages for exploration of the different datasets and their co-location. Finally, as part of this project, we used ship based profiles to study intrusions of Amazon river waters in the Virgin Islands Basin (Seijo-Ellis et al. 2023) and to validate a Regional Community Earth System Model / Modular Ocean Model 6 Configuration of the Caribbean Sea (Seijo-Ellis et al. 2024).
